ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: if you are studying and have interest in Medieval and Reformation History, i suggest you not to miss this class.
Lots of study of historiography in the field. Long final paper, but you have a lot of freedom in topic.

Prof. Eire's class provides an introduction to popular religion both as a concept and as an interpretive lens through which to approach problems of religion on medieval Europe. The syllabus was wonderfully diverse in its scope and each week had a discrete and approachable subject. If you're interested in either medieval culture or religion, this class is a must-take.
I would highly recommend this course to all Divinity students.

Weekly discussions about a book plus some recommended articles. One-two students lead discussion each week, and everyone prepares a final paper of approx. 30 pages. If you are at all interested in medieval studies, religious studies, etc., this is a great option. Very highly recommended.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: My interest area is Protestant Reformation, it was very helpful and informative for me. i am glad that i took this class, and prof. Eire is awesome!
I took this course as an undergraduate. It helped me to get a better feeling for what graduate work in history might be like.

This course allowed me the opportunity to expand my understanding of familiar subject matter using a new interpretive schema. I will be taking the questions raised in "Popular Religion" on to other classes I plan to take in the coming semester.
This course gave me an in-depth view of the topics and challenges of the study of popular religion, especially, but not limited to the early modern period.

I didn't know a lot about or have much of an interest in popular religion before I took the course but I am now very interested in popular religion or rather have realized that a lot of different things I am interested in fit under the label of popular religion.
I think that we covered a lot of ground in this course and all gained a better grasp of the slippery issue of popular religion in Europe.
